ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I know that it's a bit hard to have speakers every week, but it felt odd to go a week or two without a lecture.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Being able to hear the faculty and professors ask questions of the presenter was very revealing and informative. I learned a lot from listening to their questions.

The difference in quality of presentations was sometimes surprising. However, the lower quality presentations were actually helpful in providing insight to the research/job market process and academic hierarchy.
Hearing researchers talk about their varied interests and research process was very interesting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: In one case, a speaker seemed pretty poorly prepared, and the seminar seemed to be a dry run. In the future, someone like this speaker could probably have been better prepared, maybe by being asked to attend prior seminars.
It might have been helpful to have a little bit of explicit prep in preparing and phrasing questions.

This course is a hidden gem. Although involved in CBEY since last year, and despite having an FES econ professor as my master's degree advisor, I was unaware of this course until my second year. I understand the importance of keeping this course small and intimate, but I encourage the professors to spread the word that this seminar is open.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It is sometimes intimidating for students to ask questions, but I am not sure how this could be resolved, since students are already explicitly encouraged to participate.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I hope to get a PhD in environmental economics, so this course was a great introduction to research in the field.

This course provided a broad overview of the different types of environmental economic research that is currently being conducted. For those interested in econ research as it relates to the environment (mostly energy) then this is a great seminar.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Getting an introduction to current work in environmental economics, as well as the language of the discipline.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you're not going to engage yourself in the lectures, it's probably not worth taking it - much of the learning comes through just picking up on the language and methods used by the presenters.

This course demands very little but is a highlight of the week. It provides examples of current work in economics across a variety of fields, and helps improve vocabulary and awareness of various methodologies.

You should take this course if you want exposure to different ways that environmental economics is being applied. Each week's seminar was an interesting presentation on current environmental or natural resource economics research.
